Dr. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr.,
professor of economic geology, and
Dr. Edward B. Mathews, professor
of petrography, will attend the fifteenth International Geological
Congress, to be held at Cape Town,
South Africa, during July and August.
In addition to comment on the famous Kimberly mines which will be
visited and studied by the geologists, their program includes excursions to the cromite and manganese
mines of Rhodesia and also includes
an excursion to the famous Victoria
Falls in Rhodesia.

The International Geological
Congress is a society of geologists
,and petrographers representing every nation in the world. Every
three or four years they meet.
Dr. Singewald, who has,condcted
geological expeditions to Latin
America, and to various parts of
Europe, in addition to representing
the Johns Hopkins University, will
attend the conference as a delegate
from the American Association of
Petrolpkun Geologists, the Society of
Economic Geologists, and the Geological Society of America.
Dr. Mathews in addition to representing the petrographical department of Johns Hopkins, will attend
the congress as State geologist of
Maryland, a delegate of the National Research Council and a member of the Geological Society of
America.
Dr. Mathews and Dr. Singewald
will leave New York May 18 for
Southampton.
They plan to arrive in Capetown
July 15, in time to attend the opening excursion of the congress the
following day.
Dr. Mathews will return to Baltimore the latter part of September.
Dr. Singewald will make an overland trip through Africa with G. W.
Brabham, Government geologist of
the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. Leaving Cape Town, they will visit the
Belgian Congo, Lake Tanganyika,
Kenya Colony, Lake Victoria Nyanya in Uganda, and the head waters of the Nile. They will continue down the Nile by boat and
through the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan
to Cairo. Dr. Singewald expects to
return to Baltimore by the latter
part of October.

and buildings, blind alleys and not very definite possibilities.
But there are those who say it is as
interesting, as colorful, as alive as any
college campus. And why shouldn't,it
be? The world, too, needs menwho are

leaders of men. Men who can do new things.
Men who can make new records.
In the world's forward-looking ind,ustries, a
man's horizonl is' bounded neither by college
walls nor by an .- ether walls.
At Western Electric, the student with the
inquiring mind may carry his studies beyond
the frontiers of knowledge. The man
of action has an ever-broadening field
of endeavor. To the ultimate scope of
any one's activities there are few limits
save one's will and ability to do.

Dr. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr.,
professor of economic geology, and
Dr. Edward B. Mathews, professor
of petrography, will attend the fifteenth International Geological
Congress, to be held at Cape Town,
South Africa, during July and August.
In addition to comment on the famous Kimberly mines which will be
visited and studied by the geologists, their program includes excursions to the cromite and manganese
mines of Rhodesia and also includes
an excursion to the famous Victoria
Falls in Rhodesia.

The International Geological
Congress is a society of geologists
,and petrographers representing every nation in the world. Every
three or four years they meet.
Dr. Singewald, who has,condcted
geological expeditions to Latin
America, and to various parts of
Europe, in addition to representing
the Johns Hopkins University, will
attend the conference as a delegate
from the American Association of
Petrolpkun Geologists, the Society of
Economic Geologists, and the Geological Society of America.
Dr. Mathews in addition to representing the petrographical department of Johns Hopkins, will attend
the congress as State geologist of
Maryland, a delegate of the National Research Council and a member of the Geological Society of
America.
Dr. Mathews and Dr. Singewald
will leave New York May 18 for
Southampton.
They plan to arrive in Capetown
July 15, in time to attend the opening excursion of the congress the
following day.
Dr. Mathews will return to Baltimore the latter part of September.
Dr. Singewald will make an overland trip through Africa with G. W.
Brabham, Government geologist of
the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. Leaving Cape Town, they will visit the
Belgian Congo, Lake Tanganyika,
Kenya Colony, Lake Victoria Nyanya in Uganda, and the head waters of the Nile. They will continue down the Nile by boat and
through the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan
to Cairo. Dr. Singewald expects to
return to Baltimore by the latter
part of October.

and buildings, blind alleys and not very definite possibilities.
But there are those who say it is as
interesting, as colorful, as alive as any
college campus. And why shouldn't,it
be? The world, too, needs menwho are

leaders of men. Men who can do new things.
Men who can make new records.
In the world's forward-looking ind,ustries, a
man's horizonl is' bounded neither by college
walls nor by an .- ether walls.
At Western Electric, the student with the
inquiring mind may carry his studies beyond
the frontiers of knowledge. The man
of action has an ever-broadening field
of endeavor. To the ultimate scope of
any one's activities there are few limits
save one's will and ability to do.
